OK so found the next problem:

```
"POST /inception/v3/classify/video?mode=fixed&ext=.mp4 HTTP/1.1" 404 -
```
It's looking for a v3 video method on POST. I think it's set up to use GET.

> POST /inception/v3/classify/video?mode=fixed&ext=.mp4 HTTP/1.1" 

I think it should be going to `/inception/v4/classify/video?mode=fixed&ext=.mp4 `

The problem is OpenCV has to find FFMPEG on the given system at **compile time** and generate links. Currently , Conda's pre-built OpenCV package isn't compiled with ffmpeg support. They say ffmpeg is difficult to support across platforms. So you are only left with a single solution, you have to build OpenCV within docker.

I tested again now, it worked!
- Users are free to point to any opennlp classifier model they wish to. 
- The `modelPath` can be HTTP URL or local file path or relative path to the classloader.

I thought I handled all the cases with our awesome XML parameter binding feature.

 What did I miss?

@smadha Could you also add this fact to wiki, when running the container, it always downloads model files. If a user needs to keep those models, without downloading them again and again, they could commit those changes to the container. Once committed those changes, running the container again won't download those models. This is how to do it, 

1. First run the container by this command,

**docker run -p 8764:8764 -it inception-video-rest-tika**

2. Open another terminal, without closing the terminal which is server is running, then type this command,

**docker ps -l**

3. User will see the immediate container of inception-video-rest-tika and it's container id, make note of the container id.

4. Then by this command, changes will be committed to inception-video-rest-tika container,

**docker commit inception-video-rest-tika _container_id_**

5. To check if it's worked, stop and start the inception-video-rest-tika container again, it won't download models.

Our mac snapshots are broken /cc @huitseeker working on it . For now just use nd4j-native if you're building snapshots.
hi @agibsonccc do you know how to update the pom to use nd4j-native?

Few caveats here - mac in general is broken yet, so if you're on mac you're building from source or waiting for us to fix it. Changing the build to nd4j-native will only work for other OSes. The effect changing to nd4j-native has is making it so we only pull in the needed binary for your OS.

Getting rid of the -platform prefix is the only thing you need to do but just be warned that you should always use -platform for stable builds (at least for multi os deployment). See sam's notes above for more information on how that relates to javacpp.

@chrismattmann 

1.  the .h5 file was a big file (90MB), probably we exceeded the allowed quota and GitHub removed it? (We have been getting some notifications from GitHub, now I see it makes sense)

 2.1. There is no need to modify source code. You can place the model on localfile system and use the below config:
```xml
<properties>
  <parsers>
    <parser class="org.apache.tika.parser.recognition.ObjectRecognitionParser">
      <mime>image/jpeg</mime>
      <params>
        <param name="modelWeightsPath" type="string">/full/path/to/inception-model-weights.h5</param>
        <param name="topN" type="int">10</param>
        <param name="minConfidence" type="double">0.015</param>
        <param name="class" type="string">org.apache.tika.dl.imagerec.DL4JInceptionV3Net</param>
      </params>
    </parser>
  </parsers>
</properties>
```

2.2. Even if the model URL is HTTP, I dont think it downloads each time. It uses local cache. However, it does take 4s to 5s to initialize the inception network -- thats not downloading time.   Of course if the URL is invalid, it retries every time.

@chrismattmann that is from the reflections library, you can turn those off if you want in the logger. We use slf4j in dl4j itself so all you should need to do is set that in your tika's logging config. The warnings from dl4j are related to model validation. also controlled by the logger. 

The validation mentions this:
momentum has been set but will not be applied unless the updater is set to NESTEROVS.

We excessively warn about this because folks often forget what updater they're using.You can get rid of this if you change the momentum to 0.0 instead or change the updater.

As for the keras file, that's usually a sign of a missing file. @saudet already fixed the bug we encountered earlier.

I'm not getting a warm fuzzy here that this is stable enough to include in Tika, @thammegowda. Tests don't pass and no objects recognized on my machine using 0.8.1-SNAPSHOT. I was able to (after a lot of heavy lifting), build 0.8.1-SNAPSHOT (nd4j and libnd4j natives) - wasn't too terrible -  however each time, on the first run, I would get a SEGFAULT, then after that it never SEGFAULTED, but never produced any recognized objects. With 0.8.0, it recognizes objects, but periodically SEGFAULTS.

Not sure what to do here, I think this code needs major stabilization, not sure where the issue is. We should probably hold off on inclusion in 1.15.
I vote +1 to hold this PR for the next release (i.e 1.16) and continue releasing 1.15 without it.
hey folks, what's the good word on the PR? Seems like a reasonable improvement.

See the discussion here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TIKA-2293 .  I think there's consensus that this doesn't buy us enough and actually adds some complexity to our current setup.  I proposed moving this into a standalone project/parser that we can mention.
